Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose dependents in immigration application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the children are excluded from the 'family class' under s. 117(9)(d) due to not being examined when the applicant obtained permanent residence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, s. 117(9)(d)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Natt failed to disclose her children in her second visa application, avoiding their examination. The adoption was void, making them non-accompanying dependents at the time of her residency approval
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: The Federal Court upheld the IAD decision, confirming s. 117(9)(d) applies, and no procedural fairness breach occurred
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of IAD's dismissal of Natt's appeal
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Federal Court dismissed the application, affirming IAD's decision
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Omission of children from immigration application
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Attempt to sponsor children after non-disclosure in original application
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Interpretation and application of s. 117(9)(d) of IRPR
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Examination status of family members during sponsor’s permanent residence application
Crimes.Applicable_Legislation: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR), s. 117(9)(d)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus on legal interpretation
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa application records, adoption documentation, immigration examination records
Crimes.Application_Basis: Children not examined during sponsor’s immigration process
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Accuracy and completeness of disclosed dependents in application
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturning of IAD decision denying sponsorship eligibility
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Family members not examined cannot be part of 'family class'
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to include children in original application
Crimes.Decisional_Body: Immigration Appeal Division (IAD), reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Ineligibility of children for sponsorship under family class
Crimes.Cause_Description: Natt attempted to sponsor her children after failing to disclose them in her initial immigration application
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Reliance on official immigration records and legal status of adoption
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Lack of documentation regarding dependent children at time of application
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Compliance with examination requirements for accompanying dependents
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Documentary evidence of application and adoption status
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Regulatory exclusion applies where dependents were not examined

Crimes.Crime_Name: Immigration sponsorship ineligible due to non-examination under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the children are eligible for sponsorship as members of the 'family class' under IRPA
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, s. 117(9)(d)
Crimes.Procedural_Context: Appeal from refusal of sponsorship application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Focus on documentary accuracy rather than personal credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration application forms, adoption documents, examination records
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Children not examined during sponsor’s permanent residence process
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Non-examination of children at time of sponsor’s admission
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Administrative appeal followed by judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to list children in second visa application
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found; all relevant evidence considered
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Correct interpretation of statutory exclusion under IRPR
Crimes.Application_Factor: Dependents must be examined during sponsor’s immigration process
Crimes.Authority: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship
Crimes.Decision_Review_Issue: Correctness of regulatory application and procedural fairness
Crimes.Legal_Defense_or_Challenge: Challenge based on procedural fairness and interpretation of regulation
Crimes.Relevant_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Ineligibility under family class due to non-examination

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Eligibility for sponsorship under family class
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the children of the applicant are eligible for sponsorship under the 'family class' as per s. 117(9)(d) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, s. 117(9)(d)
Crimes.Procedural_Context: Judicial review of IAD decision dismissing appeal
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Adoption declared void, indicating false claim
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Visa application records, adoption documents, immigration examination records
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Children were not examined because they were omitted from application and falsely claimed as adopted
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Children were dependent at time of application but not disclosed or examined
Crimes.Application_Error: Omission of dependent children and submission of void adoption
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to IAD decision
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No indication that relevant evidence was ignored
Crimes.Application_Factor: Dependent children not listed or examined during immigration process
Crimes.Authority: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship
Crimes.Decision_Review_Issue: Correctness of regulatory application and procedural fairness
Crimes.Cause_of_Refusal: Omission of children and invalid adoption claim
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: False documentation (void adoption) and incomplete disclosure
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness: No breach found by Federal Court
Crimes.Legal_Defense_or_Challenge: Argument that procedural fairness was violated
Crimes.Relevant_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Ineligibility under family class due to non-examination and misrepresentation
